title: R40811
content: Severe wildfires have been burning more structures and area due to unnaturally high accumulations of biomass. Congress is being urged to provide more funding and authority for activities that reduce biomass fuels, such as prescribed burning and thinning, to lessen the severity of wildfires. Federal agencies already have broad but indirect authorities to reduce biomass fuel for wildfire protection. Federal agencies have broad but indirect authorities to reduce biomass fuel for wildfire protection. However, there is insufficient reporting on funding and accomplishments for Congress to assess progress in reducing biomass fuels. Insufficient reporting on hazardous fuel treatment funding and accomplishments hinders Congress's ability to assess progress in reducing biomass fuels for wildfire protection. More detailed information on funding sources and results from activities like prescribed burning and thinning is needed to compare benefits and costs effectively. Improved reporting on funding and results for activities like prescribed burning and thinning, disaggregated by ecosystem or fire regime, could enhance Congress's understanding of appropriations for wildfire prevention. Reducing fuel loads may not benefit protecting structures and communities from wildfires, as evidenced by the Hayman Fire in 2002 where 53% of homes were destroyed in association with torching or crown fire. The Hayman Fire in 2002, the largest wildfire in Colorado history, demonstrated the limited effectiveness of reducing fuel loads in protecting homes. 53% of homes were destroyed by torching or crown fire, while 47% were destroyed by surface fire or firebrands. Despite high-severity burns, 83% of homes within the fire perimeter survived relatively unscathed. Reducing fuel loads can help limit the extent of wildfires in surface-fire ecosystems.
